item.title: A letter to a depressed VC
item.dc:creator: sam
item.content:encoded:
Dear Eddie,
First of all, thank for you for coming to Engage Invest Exploit/TechCrunch Edinburgh and being so open in your thoughts on the Scottish startup space. This letter would not be possible, nor could any progress ever be made without you first being so honest about your feelings - so please accept my appreciation. Those that know me will know I'm not a moaner - I write this letter with the sole purpose of resolving this problem and with your assistance, will commit time and effort to achieving the desired result.
You made a statement during your panel that you're a depressed VC, and depressed for the reason that there is no innovation happening in the startup scene in Scotland. It is my opinion that we need to address this matter, and relieve you of this misery. If not to relieve you of the grey cloud, your lack of suitable investments and associated returns will eventually drive you out of business, or force you to relocate.
Firstly, let me state that I detest the general argument of "we need funding to make stuff", usually presented by companies who have failed to raise funding and don't want to take much risk themselves. I am not in this bracket of people - having founded and grown www.techmeetup.co.uk off my own back and now self-funding my new startup, www.getbloop.com. I am not rich in any way - I have just graduated from university and taken a personal loan to make my vision for Bloop happen. I am terrified.
Secondly, I am only speaking of the consumer web space here. I don't know about the world of life sciences or energy and make no relation to it.
I strongly disagree with you when you declare that there is no innovation happening in the startup space in Scotland. I have grown TechMeetup for the very purpose of uncovering what's happening, who's building what, and to bring everyone together in a startup and tech community so we can learn together, test on a local community, get feedback, introductions and support. In the last two years, the community has come together and I have seen an incredible amount of amazing developers building very cool features, products and companies. I have been to both Seedcamp and Y-combinator and I can vouch, that while the average standard at these world-class accelerators is higher, we have a number of companies that meets and surpasses these standards. From a global context, there are companies here that are worthy of attention and support. I am happy to introduce you to them but I won't name them here.
I need not explain to you in depth how the industry and ecosystem we, as entrepreneurs and VC's, live in. We (the entrepreneurs) have visions or ideas which we develop to a point that they are suitably de-risked and require capital for growth at which point we seek you. Between the concept and VC stage, there is funding required and this can come from friends and family, angels, private investors, and product revenues.
There are very few individuals in Scotland who have made money from web and this means there are very few angels who can invest money and experience back into early stage web companies here. As the local funds, including yours, mature - your minimum spend on an investment increases - and this only increases the funding gap for us at the start of a cycle. We have VC, we have startups but we have no early stage funding.
There are innovative products, bright people and great ideas here. But the lack of seed-funding means most of these can never be fully tested in the market. Furthermore, the out-dated advice uniformly handed out in Scotland, which I also oppose, is that startups should be revenue generating from day one and funding their own growth, means almost every company with an interesting idea - turns into a consultancy or a service company. We now have far more service companies and consultancies that our local market can support, and these companies will wither away.
Recently, one investor cried to me about their lack of "investable opportunities" in Scotland and I sternly responded with: "So tell me, could Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Last.fm, Spotify, Google, or any other world-class companies have grown up in Scotland? Because by your criteria, you wouldn't have funded any of them." Was Facebook innovative when you first heard of it? Was Google?
Gone are the days when a startup knocks on your door with a patent, and a need for £500,000 to bring a dying necessity to a whole untapped market. We now live in a world where we thrive on user adoption, inventing new web applications that never before existed. We don’t know how the market will respond and we don’t know what our product will look like in three years. We give people something they want, something they love, and we figure out how to monetize it when we know what people are doing with it. We now enter the era of big-data, mobile web, digital societies, and a whole array of web applications that make our lives easier, nicer and more fun to live. There will be no patents. UI design and an enjoyable experience really matter. Most of our tools are open source and we can build, release, test, and iterate in days and weeks, not months and years. For your £500,000 we can prove traction with ten companies.
Without any ability to seed fund our prototypes through to traction, none of us will be able be able to come knocking for venture capital. You run a venture capital firm, and I understand the management costs and efforts required with supporting a portfolio company - I know your model will not work when you invest £50,000 in twenty companies each year. Then I call for a new model.
Please note, that I am not commenting on your VC model or practice. I am referring to the absence of angels and seed-funding in this area and the need for you to step in with a model that can support our ecosystem and your future investments.
We can practice more lean startup methodologies, release faster, iterate quicker, focus on more international markets, refine our ideas, improve our abilities to execute, but we cannot create new angels. We cannot create more seed funding. We need your help with that - you are the ones with the money here. It will only be through working together to solve this problem that we can temporarily replace the lack of angel funding in the area. After some successes, the entrepreneurs can and should start re-investing, as angels, back into the ecosystem and you can move back to your VC model. But for now, we need your help or both you and us will either wither away or relocate.
Sam

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hello,
As someone who is just about to leave a full time job to start up my first business I could not agree more with what Sam has to say.
It appears that recently Sam has been able to begin to build a great community of people to help encourage startups but that community needs more than words and pizza to keep it going.
Personally I do believe my model will be self funding and I am doing the traditional thing of my own initial small investment and taking help from Friends/Family and any one else I can interest. However this is not easy and I now understand why it scares people out of starting in the first place.
As has been correctly pointed out here we have some of the best people in our industry in this country and some great companies have been started by them, however for the talent pool available there should be more happening.
I can only hope for myself and others that this does lead to more seed funding being made available to the right people and this in turn encourages great people not just to grow up here and be educated here but stay in Scotland. Then again maybe we just don't have the weather for that ;)
Hope to see you are the next TechMeetup.
Take care.

There is a huge gap in early stage venture financing, Sam is right.
Sam is right. Google, Facebook, you name it, would have never happened here in Scotland.
Its sizable, the gap. It makes all the difference and leads to poor comparable advantage for the State / Region.
Moreover, there is not enough spend in the R & D stage at the university or corporate levels. (As a % of GDP). Especially for an educated, remote, Western Country.
Two big problems.
Israel had the second solved and had a problem with the first. When the first was finally solved through government intervention and the creation of more venture capital supply quickly ensued, the tech start-up scene zoomed. Its now the leader in this category.
This entrepreneurial finance gap also exists in the Silicon Valley. And there is agreement that the current venture capital model is broken. No doubt. Experiments like Y-Combinator are solving a piece of the problem.
Supply creates demand; the supply of risk capital leads to the creation of more innovative start-ups. Entrepreneurs go to where the risk capital is, they are mobile in the world as creatives (refer to Richard Florida's "Flight of the Creative Class").
The problem in Scotland, like many regions, is the lack of competition amongst venture capitalists, and risk capitalists (including angels) that invest in a particular sector.
Thus the equation:
More supply = more competition = more competitive start-ups.
Its not the supply of management or marketing talent, despite what "they say". Talent will migrate to the risk capital in this game. It will move where it is present.
Solve the supply of risk capital and competition between risk capital players factors, and innovative start-ups will increase dramatically. While you're at it, more R & D.
-Clouser

What if the Angel and VC community in partnership with universities ran a Mobile & Web business creation competition.
Such as the MIT $100K or Cambridge's CUE competitions:
http://www.cue.org.uk/competition
OR does the community want/need a Y-Combinator, Seedcamp or Launch48?
We hope to create 12 startups out of:
http://mobile-apps.masf-prospekt.sgizmo.com
But we need to be creating 100's of these a year so that half a dozen evolve into real opportunities for the likes of Pentech.
I also think a fusion of the creative and developer communities in Edinburgh will help, as we are more likely to get useful product ideas this way. There's some overlap of people, such as we had yesterday at EIE. Also get developers reaching out to non techies for product ideas.
e.g. 65 percent of Orthopaedic Surgeons in Edinburgh have iPhones. There's an App for that opportunity there.
Hack weekends, competitions, we need 1000X more product concepts for a few to fly.
We need many of our startups to think about combining, partnering, merging and acquiring.
We need to kill crap ideas.
And we need 1000X Sam Collins.
Hustle.
Andrew

I think it's a combination of lack of faith/money for early stagers and lack of people willing to take risks and join. The atmosphere over here in the Valley is so different yet the number of bright, enthusiastic and talented people in Scotland was possibly higher (there are a lot of 'wannabe rockstars' here).
I would never have got my company off the ground without the support of EPIS, investing £10k through Scottish Enterprise. 10k. That's all it took. I then raised further money for expansion and for Festbuzz, which itself required specific outlay due to the festival, but even then the total amount I raised is apparently a 'rounding error' in VCs' books.
And yet the key difference between Scotland and the Valley is the number of people here who've actually done it before, who'll get behind you 100%, and who might even commit to join your startup long before you see revenue. Wonderful though the advisors and mentors I have in Scotland are, they were revenue focused and staring at the ground from day one, whereas I'm looking up at the sky imagining how things could look. I think you need a balance, I definitely think Scotland needs more mentors and investors who get the lean, web-2.0 model, and ideally more schemes like EPIS/Y-Combinator/Seedcamp to provide ramen funding and advice while smart people take some time to build something that works and test it out.
It was partly my own fault, but also partly that of the ecosystem, that I spent so long faffing about trying to find a product that would pay my rent from day one - while trying not to become a consultancy - that I never truly built my idea out to the full potential of my initial vision. Something I'm trying to correct now. ;)
--J (a Scottish/English/Welsh export to the Valley, who fully intends to come back a billionaire and invest in young Scottish startups!)

Kevin, my argument is that locally, we lack angels who can support web companies. It believe this is one of the major factors for Eddie not receiving more innovative investment opportunities.
We need to fix the early funding stage up here. There are other problems, but they can be solved by ourselves. For the funding side, we need help from others.
I'm proposing that if Eddie wants more innovative investment proposals, he could help us out at the early stage funding part. Now maybe this is an early stage, rapid dev incubator with small sums of money and top priority is proof of traction. Maybe it is breaking up some of the syndicates so individual angels can move faster. Maybe it means that the venture capitalist such as Eddie look at adapting a new early stage strategy (needs a different model to their growth capital one).
I'm openly calling for help on this. There are many ways we can resolve the situation, but all of them require us changing our current way of life.

Nice one Sam.
Just about to launch our new startup which we're bootstrapping too. I know there are quite a few out there that are following the same model, and I think we're going to see a lot more in the next 12 months.
Colin

Hi Sam
Thanks for this. On reflection, I was overly negative, and partly to take an extreme position to get some discussion going. I definitely could have articulated what I was trying to say a bit better.
I don’t think I said there is no innovation (or didn’t mean to), just that there isn’t enough innovation given the size of the talent pool. You and bloop are a great example. You have come up with an interesting idea, and are trying to bootstrap the business, which is great! Given the lack of capital required to get companies off the ground, and to get marketing going, we should be seeing more companies appear.
Sadly, we spend more time in our London office than we do in our Edinburgh office, and I wish it wasn't the case.
But, it is easy to sit on a panel and criticise, and more than happy to chat about the role we can play to make things better.
Eddie

"Given the lack of capital required to get companies off the ground, and to get marketing going, we should be seeing more companies appear."
You still need web development, design, maybe even mobile apps. It's unlikely that you can get founders with each skill who can work for free. A flight to California and a ticket to a tech conference/exhibition will cost a few thousand pounds.
Founders should definitely be putting their money where their mouth is, nobody gets to start a company for free. But there should be quick investment options for sharp founders who are building something great and need to get out there, with a killer product...fast.
The probability of having great founders with all the right skill sets who can work for nothing and fund the right expenses with a compelling product is very close to zero.

I've read your letter but I'm not sure what, where and how to show my support for it. To be clear are you appealing that Angels need to start making more investments in young Scottish companies to see more local quality future investments arise? Are you planning on pushing this letter in some more directions? Is it solely intended for the investment company for which Eddie works?
I agree with you that if there were more investment there would be more opportunity for investment but I also agree with Eddie I'm afraid when it comes to the amount of current investable opportunities. Maybe it's different where you are in particular in Edinburgh, I've been very happy to watch Techmeetup grow within the Edinburgh circle but this is totally localised and very recent. Generally elsewhere in Scotland it's not as positive.
I completely agree that: * New Tech businesses in Scotland are regularly given outdated advice.
I have experienced this with all 3 businesses I have started/worked in. In my experience if you are a tech startup specialist Scottish advice is unavailable and sadly a hinderance. This is improving now that these businesses are being taken more seriously and being networked together, but in general I commonly encoutered old men/women who feel threatened at the prospect of being corrected when offering any advice to technology based startups and so stick to what they know and do not go out of their way to help technology businesses like they would a bricks and mortar establishment.
The climate in general climate in Scotland apart from Edinburgh's Uni, is not encouraging for small technology businesses and anything I can do to help you express this I'd love to help.
I had to move to London to even get started, I'm not saying I imagine the London hub of activity in the UK changing but it shouldn't be necessary at the beginning stages. I should have been able to get a foot up in Scotland.

This is going to sound like a rant, but having been through the Scotland entrepreneurship scene, having tried and failed, I feel I should say something...
I whole-heartedly agree with you that we need more Angels in Scotland. And the ones who think they are, should ask themselves if they really are.
How do you define an 'Angel', and how are they different from regular VCs or Bankers? Is the distinction just having a little risk-taking and recklessness, or a little eagerness to help new startups, or to have faith in people more than the product or the idea.
But this is also what Charities do. What distinguishes an Angel, in my opinion, is their passion to see amazing cutting-edge technologies happen. More than making money on the next big thing, or riding the next big wave, they want to make that next big thing happen. Its their love of innovation, not profits.
I don't see a lack of people in Scotland who are willing to dream big, and act on it. I have seen entrepreneurs develop amazing technologies and not being able to do anything with it. They are able to get a few thousand pounds from university grants, and try to build something out of it. Living cheaply and working 17 hrs a day, they try to take it to the next step.
And then they meet a VC who asks them: there are companies in the valley who are doing this, how can you do this? When I was trying to make a new search engine, a well-known VC asked me, "Google, Yahoo are already there. If I was you, I would go get a job". Of course they are there, I knew that even before I started!
The core of the issue is this: do you believe that the next big thing can come from Scotland? Do the VCs, Angels in Scotland believe that cutting-edge innovation can happen in Scotland?
If they don't then shouldn't be here, and go to the Valley or London, or wherever they are inspired by. But if you do, help make things happen here. Can we for a moment stop looking at the Valley and do something on our own. Rather than copying everything that comes out of the Valley, can we believe in ourselves, and focus on making things truly amazing and innovative?
Everyone wants the fruits but no one wants to plant the trees!
Arnav

Perhaps we should have a proper public debate about this?
Especially interesting the day after Archangel Informal Investment gets behind vibio.com with $1 million.
Andrew

Hey Sam,
A very timely article for me. The fact that there is very little funding for companies starting up has had me wondering about re-investing down the lane in Scottish startups. There are some really bright innovative students and projects that take place within the boundaries of the university that can be developed further with the help of local investors and advice. I am hoping to be part of this ecosystem and absolutely support what you have mentioned in your letter above.
-Grishma @strangeloops
Very honest. Good work Sam.

I agree with you Sam. I think the Scottish VC's should be worried. The London VC's have responded to the Seed Funding issue by putting together Seedcamp and Sequoia have now invested directly in YCombinator as their seed accelerator. These models both address the investor attention deficit that results from the VC's deal size being (Total Fund)/(NoOfPartners*NoOfBoardSeatsEach).
In Web 1.0 when we did IF.com our main servers were £1.5m the pair - deal size and first round funding were in step.
The Scottish VC's haven't responded to this world and the result is clear. The TechMeetup Scene has now send a squad of applicants to London for Seedcamp and the Valley for YCombinator.
Eddie's point about nobody coming out of JP Morgan showed this point very well as at least one startup team leaving Glasgow for London to try and get into the Seedcamp ecosystem.
These new accelorator funding structures over small experimental amounts of money and loads of contacts, mentoring, help, advice, access to key hires.
By the time Pentech appear on the scene the global ambitious startups have flown the coop.
As a former Parliamentary Candidate for the SNP I don't wake up every morning thinking "how can I best help Scottish talent leave for the US, or worse, London"...
The start-up teams in Scotland now have a strong culture of constructive criticism - tell me what I am doing wrong. We are entitled to put all the fundering organisations under the same amount of scrutiny.
Why should I take any funding from any of the local VCs? Why shouldn't I try and go to London or the Valley? Tell us how you are competing with the best in the game. Tell us how you are adapting to the new world - because at the moment we just don't see it.

Andrew,
I fully love everything you do - huge respect. It amazing to be able to enlighten the students so much and push them to their max.
However from a lean startup incubator point of view, I think it's important to be significantly detached from universities and public sector for only two reasons - 1) speed of decision making and 2) metrics for success.
I personally think that startups at this stage should have no strings attached. It's all about speed and insightful decisions made quickly (sometimes without the evidence to support the decision). A public sector or university supported incubator brings with it it's own remits it needs to achieve - which are sometimes more than those of the startup.
Please contest if you feel otherwise.

"Clouser" - it seems counter intuitive, but I agree - the supply creates demand here. Does anyone remember when 4iP started and their message sounded something like "we'll fund your startup on your terms"? Startups came out of the wood-work everywhere. Ewan was swamped in applications. I was astonished - I'm sure a ton of them sucked, but like I said - we can fix the problem of badly focused ideas, inexperienced people: FUND THEM. But under lean startup rules - MVP and iterate seriously fast.

Totally agree with you Sam.
Trying our best at Informatics to challenge this status quo though; and to work at startup clockspeeds (not to mention crazy startup hours).
My remit and metrics are in total harmony with yours and those of startups. More companies, more jobs, more products or services, more sales, more profit. More deals.
And Total Global Domination!
I hope this discussion builds up and we can take some positive action from it.
Also Clouser is so right to point us at Israel.
Andrew

This is a healthy discussion. Before I became a VC, I bootsrapped my company, and then raised funding from angels, and so I empathise more than most.
There are real issues for both entrepreneurs and VCs. For entrepreneurs, their aren't enough tech savvy angels to provide the small amounts of capital to help prove ideas. Archangel does a great job, but doesn't address this issue. London is better, and California is the best.

I am just back from the American Angel Capital Conference held in San Francisco last week.
Interesting to read the comments here.
So much talk about creating great applications / technology etc. Frankly, why should any invertors, VC or angel care?
If you wish to create a dynamic investment community you need to demonstrate that the investors are more likely to make money by looking at companies here than anywhere else (on the planet).
That means building and selling companies. A company is only a success from an investment perspective when it has made money for it’s investors. Its only by going through the build / sell process that you create fully experienced entrepreneurs that investors will back again and again.
So stop talking about technology and start talking financial return.
One of the key speakers at the ACA was Ronald Conway - an active angel investor for over 15 years.
He was the Founder and Managing Partner of the Angel Investors LP funds (1998-2005) whose investments included: Google, Ask Jeeves, Paypal, Good Technology, Opsware, and Brightmail.
Featured in Gary Rivlin’s book The Godfather of Silicon Valley: Ron Conway and the Fall of the Dot-coms, he is described as ‘the man who has placed more bets on Internet start-ups than anyone else in Silicon Valley.
Ron receives 100s of proposals a month from Bay area companies. He has invested in over 500 (asked about international investing he said he had once done an investment in Los Angelis!)
His message to companies looking for funding – upon hearing the initial pitch, if within 10 seconds he cannot think of 5 companies who would be potential acquirers of the pitching company he will not take the discussion further.
Now that is perhaps a bit extreme – but I think the message is clear – What investors are looking for are entrepreneurs who can build a company (not a technology) to an exit - who can on day one identify who is likely to be the acquiring company (that may change with time but who is out there now), and explain their plan to get that acquirers attention.
By the way- discussions at the ACA show that a “good exit” in the US is considered to be one where the entrepreneur walks away with $10m – so lets not fantasize about $100m+ IPO’s.

The life sciences sector is trying to work out how to implement a 'fail fast' (will to kill) methodology, and is looking at 'asset-centric' funding, ie funding projects rather than companies, so that infrastructure can be shared and company self-protectionism avoided. item.title: Aberdeen Techmeetup #7 (May 2010)
item.dc:creator: gavin
item.content:encoded: Even with good weather we had a decent crowd indoors with some new faces, which is good to see. Gordon Murrison on From 35,000 feet to a shipping product Gordon broke his talk into a design part and an engineering part. In the design part he told us that user experience (ux) is becoming just as important as writing good code. You do need to think of your users. Features make the ux and these need to start small and grow. However, you can't put in what you think is 'cool' but rather think of the whole, and how by removing features you can actually make a better product. This is how the coffee grinder at his office works: it's so well desigend you can't use it wrong, and that's how our software should be too. Don't add features that will detract from the message of your software. As to the engineering side of things, he focused on three parts: source control, unit testing and automation. Use source control to keep everything in one place, and use its branching and tagging features appropriately. With unit testing we should test early and test often as a means to keep your code in line and and build confidence in the codebase for the futrue. Lastly, let automation take the strain of doing repetitive tasks for us so that we don't have to do them by hand which also reduces human error. He recommended Cruise Control.rb as a way to automate the build system, which he also recommended putting in place right at the start so that you know what integration issues are there and that they can be resolved early in the process. He finished by showing his build monitoring system that provides visual feedback of the state of the build by hooking up red and green lamps. Martin Evans on Arduino and Ruby Martin told us about using the the open source hardware boards based on Arduino, and how you can add shields to them for extra functionality like wifi, Bluetooth and USB, as well as adding a variety of sensors too. He then compared the given arduino software programming language with doing it all using the Ruby Arduino Development gem, which is much simpler to use: rake make:upload and away you go. You can also use a variety of plugins in this as you do with other ruby projects. Lastly, we had a short demo of his robot car which uses sensors to detect objects and avoid collisions and a discussion about the affordability of Arduino projects. Afterwards it was time for more beer and pizza while discussing the evenings talks. Thanks to all who came, and remember next time to bring a friend. Videos of both presentations will be online in the next few days.

item.dc:creator: gavin
item.content:encoded: We had a good turnout at last night's techmeetup, with some familiar faces, some new faces and even a window-blind manufacturer who'd come to see what his friend was up to (cue jokes about Window developers). First up was Nikhil Ninan who shared with us some of his research on IP-based multicast delivery over DVB networks. After explaining current delivery mechanisms, Nikhil described the Robust Header Compression (ROHC) standard for the compression of internet packet headers. He went on to describe how his investigations show that by delivering MPEG-4 over ROHC a delivery efficiency similar to that of MPEG-2 over DBV can be achieved. Nikhil finished by outlining the direction of his future work which will involve, for example, the analysis of real live ROHC implementations. After Nikhil, Alan Spark took to the stage to tell us about Code Rocket. Code Rocket is a very nicely implemented procedural level design tool which integrates with both Visual Studio (C# and C++) and Eclipse (Java), providing both pseudocode and flowchart editors. Alan demonstrated some of Code Rocket's round-trip editing features with a spot of live development; a bold move, but one which payed off.

item.content:encoded: Techmeetup #12 will be held on Wednesday 23rd June, 7:00pm-late, in space generously donated by the Glasgow Media Access Centre (GMAC for short).  GMAC is located on the fifth floor of Trongate 103 - come checkout the new digs! TechMeetup is a monthly get together for tech chat, talks, pizza & beer - turn up around 7pm and we'll be there to welcome you and introduce you to the nearest members of the local tech community.  Whether you're a code monkey, a designer, an academic, a start-up addict or you're running an established business, you'll meet folks walking your talk. Following a bit of chat we generally kick off 1 or 2 informal talks on topics covering the desktop, mobile, & console, some leading Scottish lights in the commercial environment, and then some academic stuff I didn't understand - check out the videos for more background! Up this month we have Matt Wynne on Behavioural Driven Development with Cucumber.  Matt's a long-time evangelist of agile development and comes with some great experience from the likes of SongKick.com and the BBC. Examples are one of the most powerful tools we have for learning. When we build digital media for people, we want to learn as much as possible about what they want, as quickly as possible, in order to build them just the right thing. Using examples to explore and capture requirements is a great way to bridge the communication gap between stakeholders and programmers, and discover any misunderstandings or false assumptions. Cucumber is a tool for writing these examples in a format that can easily be read by both stakeholders and, crucially, the computer itself. By making them machine-readable, we can build up a suite of executable requirements (or acceptance tests) which you can use to check the behaviour of the system as it's built. Matt will describe Cucumber, explain why we need it, and show some examples of how it can be used to create better digital media faster. P.S. arrive 7pm sharpish or you'll miss the pizza!
